segment.source: This topic discusses the LoadState command syntax and options.
segment.target: This topic discusses the LoadState command syntax and options.

segment.source: Before you run the LoadState command, note the following:
segment.target: Before you run the LoadState command, note the following:

segment.source: To ensure that all operating system settings migrate, we recommend that you run the LoadState commands in administrator mode from an account with administrative credentials.
segment.target: To ensure that all operating system settings migrate, we recommend that you run the LoadState commands in administrator mode from an account with administrative credentials.

segment.source: For information about software requirements for running the LoadState command, see USMT Requirements.
segment.target: For information about software requirements for running the LoadState command, see USMT Requirements.

segment.source: You should log off after you run the LoadState command.
segment.target: You should log off after you run the LoadState command.

segment.source: Some settings (for example, fonts, wallpaper, and screensaver settings) will not take effect until the next time the user logs in.
segment.target: Some settings (for example, fonts, wallpaper, and screensaver settings) will not take effect until the next time the user logs in.

segment.source: Unless otherwise specified, you can use each option only once when running a tool on the command line.
segment.target: Unless otherwise specified, you can use each option only once when running a tool on the command line.

segment.source: LoadState does not require domain controller access to apply domain profiles.
segment.target: LoadState does not require domain controller access to apply domain profiles.

segment.source: This functionality is available without any additional configuration.
segment.target: This functionality is available without any additional configuration.

segment.source: It is not necessary for the source computer to have had domain controller access when the user profile was gathered using ScanState.
segment.target: It is not necessary for the source computer to have had domain controller access when the user profile was gathered using ScanState.

segment.source: However, domain profiles are inaccessible until the destination computer is joined to the domain.
segment.target: However, domain profiles are inaccessible until the destination computer is joined to the domain.

segment.source: The Incompatible Command-Line Options table lists which options you can use together and which command-line options are incompatible.
segment.target: The Incompatible Command-Line Options table lists which options you can use together and which command-line options are incompatible.

segment.source: This section explains the syntax and usage of the command-line options available when you use the LoadState command.
segment.target: This section explains the syntax and usage of the command-line options available when you use the LoadState command.

segment.source: The options can be specified in any order.
segment.target: The options can be specified in any order.

segment.source: If the option contains a parameter, you can specify either a colon or space separator.
segment.target: If the option contains a parameter, you can specify either a colon or space separator.

segment.source: For example, to decrypt the store and migrate the files and settings to a computer running Windows 7 type the following on the command line:
segment.target: For example, to decrypt the store and migrate the files and settings to a computer running Windows 7 type the following on the command line:

segment.source: USMT provides the following options that you can use to specify how and where the migrated data is stored.
segment.target: USMT provides the following options that you can use to specify how and where the migrated data is stored.

segment.source: Indicates the folder where the files and settings data are stored.
segment.target: Indicates the folder where the files and settings data are stored.

segment.source: You must specify StorePath when using the LoadState command.
segment.target: You must specify StorePath when using the LoadState command.

segment.source: You cannot specify more than one StorePath.
segment.target: You cannot specify more than one StorePath.

segment.source: Decrypts the store with the specified key.
segment.target: Decrypts the store with the specified key.

segment.source: With this option, you will need to specify the encryption key in one of the following ways:
segment.target: With this option, you will need to specify the encryption key in one of the following ways:

segment.source: If there is a space in KeyString, you must surround the argument with quotation marks.
segment.target: If there is a space in KeyString, you must surround the argument with quotation marks.

segment.source: /keyfile:FilePathAndName specifies a text (.txt) file that contains the encryption key
segment.target: /keyfile:FilePathAndName specifies a text (.txt) file that contains the encryption key

segment.source: The /key and /keyfile options cannot be used on the same command line.
segment.target: The /key and /keyfile options cannot be used on the same command line.

segment.source: The /decrypt and /nocompress options cannot be used on the same command line.
segment.target: The /decrypt and /nocompress options cannot be used on the same command line.

segment.source: Use caution with this option, because anyone who has access to the LoadState command-line script will also have access to the encryption key.
segment.target: Use caution with this option, because anyone who has access to the LoadState command-line script will also have access to the encryption key.

segment.source: The /decrypt option accepts a command-line parameter to define the encryption strength specified for the migration store encryption.
segment.target: The /decrypt option accepts a command-line parameter to define the encryption strength specified for the migration store encryption.

segment.source: For more information about supported encryption algorithms, see Migration Store Encryption.
segment.target: For more information about supported encryption algorithms, see Migration Store Encryption.

segment.source: Enables user-state data to be restored from a hard-link migration store.
segment.target: Enables user-state data to be restored from a hard-link migration store.

segment.source: The /nocompress parameter must be specified with /hardlink option.
segment.target: The /nocompress parameter must be specified with /hardlink option.

segment.source: Specifies that the store is not compressed.
segment.target: Specifies that the store is not compressed.

segment.source: You should only use this option in testing environments.
segment.target: You should only use this option in testing environments.

segment.source: We recommend that you use a compressed store during your actual migration.
segment.target: We recommend that you use a compressed store during your actual migration.

segment.source: This option cannot be used with the /decrypt option.
segment.target: This option cannot be used with the /decrypt option.

segment.source: USMT provides the following options to specify what files you want to migrate.
segment.target: USMT provides the following options to specify what files you want to migrate.

segment.source: Specifies an .xml file that contains rules that define what state to migrate.
segment.target: Specifies an .xml file that contains rules that define what state to migrate.

segment.source: You can specify this option multiple times to include all of your .xml files (MigApp.xml, MigSys.xml, MigDocs.xml and any custom .xml files that you create).
segment.target: You can specify this option multiple times to include all of your .xml files (MigApp.xml, MigSys.xml, MigDocs.xml and any custom .xml files that you create).

segment.source: Path can be either a relative or full path.
segment.target: Path can be either a relative or full path.

segment.source: If you do not specify the Path variable, then FileName must be located in the current directory.
segment.target: If you do not specify the Path variable, then FileName must be located in the current directory.

segment.source: For more information about which files to specify, see the XML files section of the Frequently Asked Questions topic.
segment.target: For more information about which files to specify, see the XML files section of the Frequently Asked Questions topic.

segment.source: Specifies the Config.xml file that the LoadState command should use.
segment.target: Specifies the Config.xml file that the LoadState command should use.

segment.source: You cannot specify this option more than once on the command line.
segment.target: You cannot specify this option more than once on the command line.

segment.source: Path can be either a relative or full path.
segment.target: Path can be either a relative or full path.

segment.source: If you do not specify the Path variable, then the FileName must be located in the current directory.
segment.target: If you do not specify the Path variable, then the FileName must be located in the current directory.

segment.source: This example migrates the files and settings based on the rules in the Config.xml, MigDocs.xml, and MigApp.xml files:
segment.target: This example migrates the files and settings based on the rules in the Config.xml, MigDocs.xml, and MigApp.xml files:

segment.source: This option enables you to specify the location of the default .xml files and then launch your migration.
segment.target: This option enables you to specify the location of the default .xml files and then launch your migration.

segment.source: If no path is specified, USMT will use the directory where the USMT binaries are located.
segment.target: If no path is specified, USMT will use the directory where the USMT binaries are located.

segment.source: The /auto option has the same effect as using the following options: /i:MigDocs.xml/i:MigApp.xml /v:5.
segment.target: The /auto option has the same effect as using the following options: /i:MigDocs.xml/i:MigApp.xml /v:5.

segment.source: USMT provides several command-line options that you can use to analyze problems that occur during migration.
segment.target: USMT provides several command-line options that you can use to analyze problems that occur during migration.

segment.source: Specifies the location and name of the LoadState log.
segment.target: Specifies the location and name of the LoadState log.

segment.source: You cannot store any of the log files in StorePath.
segment.target: You cannot store any of the log files in StorePath.

segment.source: Path can be either a relative or full path.
segment.target: Path can be either a relative or full path.

segment.source: If you do not specify the Path variable, then the log will be created in the current directory.
segment.target: If you do not specify the Path variable, then the log will be created in the current directory.

segment.source: You can specify the /v option to adjust the amount of output.
segment.target: You can specify the /v option to adjust the amount of output.

segment.source: If you run the LoadState command from a shared network resource, you must specify this option or USMT will fail with the error: USMT was unable to create the log file(s).
segment.target: If you run the LoadState command from a shared network resource, you must specify this option or USMT will fail with the error: USMT was unable to create the log file(s).

segment.source: To fix this issue, use the /l:load.log option.
segment.target: To fix this issue, use the /l:load.log option.

segment.source: Enables verbose output in the LoadState log file.
segment.target: Enables verbose output in the LoadState log file.

segment.source: You can set the VerbosityLevel to one of the following levels:
segment.target: You can set the VerbosityLevel to one of the following levels:

segment.source: Only the default errors and warnings are enabled.
segment.target: Only the default errors and warnings are enabled.

segment.source: Enables error output to a debugger.
segment.target: Enables error output to a debugger.

segment.source: Enables verbose output to a debugger.
segment.target: Enables verbose output to a debugger.

segment.source: Enables error and status output to a debugger.
segment.target: Enables error and status output to a debugger.

segment.source: Enables verbose, status, and debugger output.
segment.target: Enables verbose, status, and debugger output.

segment.source: You cannot store any of the log files in StorePath.
segment.target: You cannot store any of the log files in StorePath.

segment.source: Path can be either a relative or full path.
segment.target: Path can be either a relative or full path.

segment.source: If you do not specify the Path variable, then FileName will be created in the current directory.
segment.target: If you do not specify the Path variable, then FileName will be created in the current directory.

segment.source: When this option is specified, the LoadState command will continue to run, even if non-fatal errors occur.
segment.target: When this option is specified, the LoadState command will continue to run, even if non-fatal errors occur.

segment.source: Any files or settings that cause an error are logged in the progress log.
segment.target: Any files or settings that cause an error are logged in the progress log.

segment.source: For example, if there is a large file that will not fit on the computer, the LoadState command will log an error and continue with the migration.
segment.target: For example, if there is a large file that will not fit on the computer, the LoadState command will log an error and continue with the migration.

segment.source: Without the /c option, the LoadState command will exit on the first error.
segment.target: Without the /c option, the LoadState command will exit on the first error.

segment.source: You can use the new ErrorControl section in the Config.xml file to specify which file or registry read/write errors can be safely ignored and which might cause the migration to fail.
segment.target: You can use the new ErrorControl section in the Config.xml file to specify which file or registry read/write errors can be safely ignored and which might cause the migration to fail.

segment.source: This enables the /c command-line option to safely skip all input/output (I/O) errors in your environment.
segment.target: This enables the /c command-line option to safely skip all input/output (I/O) errors in your environment.

segment.source: In addition, the /genconfig option now generates a sample ErrorControl section that is enabled by specifying error messages and desired behaviors in the Config.xml file.
segment.target: In addition, the /genconfig option now generates a sample ErrorControl section that is enabled by specifying error messages and desired behaviors in the Config.xml file.

segment.source: Specifies the number of times to retry when an error occurs while migrating the user state from a server.
segment.target: Specifies the number of times to retry when an error occurs while migrating the user state from a server.

segment.source: This option is useful in environments where network connectivity is not reliable.
segment.target: This option is useful in environments where network connectivity is not reliable.

segment.source: While restoring the user state, the /r option will not recover data that is lost due to a network-hardware failure, such as a faulty or disconnected network cable, or when a virtual private network (VPN) connection fails.
segment.target: While restoring the user state, the /r option will not recover data that is lost due to a network-hardware failure, such as a faulty or disconnected network cable, or when a virtual private network (VPN) connection fails.

segment.source: The retry option is intended for large, busy networks where connectivity is satisfactory, but communication latency is a problem.
segment.target: The retry option is intended for large, busy networks where connectivity is satisfactory, but communication latency is a problem.

segment.source: Specifies the time to wait, in seconds, before retrying a network file operation.
segment.target: Specifies the time to wait, in seconds, before retrying a network file operation.

segment.source: Displays Help on the command line.
segment.target: Displays Help on the command line.

segment.source: By default, all users are migrated.
segment.target: By default, all users are migrated.

segment.source: The only way to specify which users to include and exclude is by using the following options.
segment.target: The only way to specify which users to include and exclude is by using the following options.

segment.source: You cannot exclude users in the migration .xml files or by using the Config.xml file.
segment.target: You cannot exclude users in the migration .xml files or by using the Config.xml file.

segment.source: For more information, see Identify Users.
segment.target: For more information, see Identify Users.

segment.source: Migrates all of the users on the computer.
segment.target: Migrates all of the users on the computer.

segment.source: USMT migrates all user accounts on the computer, unless you specifically exclude an account with the /ue or /uel options.
segment.target: USMT migrates all user accounts on the computer, unless you specifically exclude an account with the /ue or /uel options.

segment.source: For this reason, you do not need to specify this option on the command line.
segment.target: For this reason, you do not need to specify this option on the command line.

segment.source: However, if you choose to use the /all option, you cannot also use the /ui, /ue or /uel options.
segment.target: However, if you choose to use the /all option, you cannot also use the /ui, /ue or /uel options.

segment.source: By default, all users are included in the migration.
segment.target: By default, all users are included in the migration.

segment.source: Therefore, this option is helpful only when used with the /ue option.
segment.target: Therefore, this option is helpful only when used with the /ue option.

segment.source: You can specify multiple /ui options, but you cannot use the /ui option with the /all option.
segment.target: You can specify multiple /ui options, but you cannot use the /ui option with the /all option.

segment.source: DomainName and UserName can contain the asterisk (*) wildcard character.
segment.target: DomainName and UserName can contain the asterisk (*) wildcard character.

segment.source: When you specify a user name that contains spaces, you will need to surround it with quotations marks.
segment.target: When you specify a user name that contains spaces, you will need to surround it with quotations marks.

segment.source: To include only User2 from the Corporate domain, type:
segment.target: To include only User2 from the Corporate domain, type:

segment.source: If a user is specified for inclusion with the /ui option, and also is specified to be excluded with either the /ue or /uel options, the user will be included in the migration.
segment.target: If a user is specified for inclusion with the /ui option, and also is specified to be excluded with either the /ue or /uel options, the user will be included in the migration.

segment.source: For more examples, see the descriptions of the /uel, /ue, and /ui options in this table.
segment.target: For more examples, see the descriptions of the /uel, /ue, and /ui options in this table.

segment.source: Migrates only the users that logged onto the source computer within the specified time period, based on the Last Modified date of the Ntuser.dat file on the source computer.
segment.target: Migrates only the users that logged onto the source computer within the specified time period, based on the Last Modified date of the Ntuser.dat file on the source computer.

segment.source: The /uel option acts as an include rule.
segment.target: The /uel option acts as an include rule.

segment.source: For example, the /uel:30 option migrates users who logged on, or whose user account was modified, within the last 30 days from the date when the ScanState command is run.
segment.target: For example, the /uel:30 option migrates users who logged on, or whose user account was modified, within the last 30 days from the date when the ScanState command is run.

segment.source: You can specify a number of days or you can specify a date.
segment.target: You can specify a number of days or you can specify a date.

segment.source: You cannot use this option with the /all option.
segment.target: You cannot use this option with the /all option.

segment.source: USMT retrieves the last logon information from the local computer, so the computer does not need to be connected to the network when you run this option.
segment.target: USMT retrieves the last logon information from the local computer, so the computer does not need to be connected to the network when you run this option.

segment.source: In addition, if a domain user has logged onto another computer, that logon instance is not considered by USMT.
segment.target: In addition, if a domain user has logged onto another computer, that logon instance is not considered by USMT.

segment.source: The /uel option is not valid in offline migrations.
segment.target: The /uel option is not valid in offline migrations.

segment.source: migrates accounts that were logged on to the source computer when the ScanState command was run.
segment.target: migrates accounts that were logged on to the source computer when the ScanState command was run.

segment.source: migrates users who have logged on, or whose accounts have been otherwise modified, within the last 90 days.
segment.target: migrates users who have logged on, or whose accounts have been otherwise modified, within the last 90 days.

segment.source: migrates users whose accounts have been modified within the last 24 hours.
segment.target: migrates users whose accounts have been modified within the last 24 hours.

segment.source: migrates users who have logged on or whose accounts have been modified since January 15, 2002.
segment.target: migrates users who have logged on or whose accounts have been modified since January 15, 2002.

segment.source: Excludes the specified users from the migration.
segment.target: Excludes the specified users from the migration.

segment.source: You can specify multiple /ue options but you cannot use the /ue option with the /all option.
segment.target: You can specify multiple /ue options but you cannot use the /ue option with the /all option.

segment.source: DomainName and UserName can contain the asterisk (*) wildcard character.
segment.target: DomainName and UserName can contain the asterisk (*) wildcard character.

segment.source: When you specify a user name that contains spaces, you will need to surround it with quotation marks.
segment.target: When you specify a user name that contains spaces, you will need to surround it with quotation marks.

segment.source: For more examples, see the descriptions of the /uel, /ue, and /ui options in this table.
segment.target: For more examples, see the descriptions of the /uel, /ue, and /ui options in this table.

segment.source: Specifies a new domain for the user.
segment.target: Specifies a new domain for the user.

segment.source: Use this option to change the domain for users on a computer or to migrate a local user to a domain account.
segment.target: Use this option to change the domain for users on a computer or to migrate a local user to a domain account.

segment.source: OldDomain may contain the asterisk (*) wildcard character.
segment.target: OldDomain may contain the asterisk (*) wildcard character.

segment.source: You can specify this option more than once.
segment.target: You can specify this option more than once.

segment.source: You may want to specify multiple /md options if you are consolidating users across multiple domains to a single domain.
segment.target: You may want to specify multiple /md options if you are consolidating users across multiple domains to a single domain.

segment.source: For example, you could specify the following to consolidate the users from the Corporate and FarNorth domains into the Fabrikam domain: and .
segment.target: For example, you could specify the following to consolidate the users from the Corporate and FarNorth domains into the Fabrikam domain: and .

segment.source: If there are conflicts between two /md commands, the first rule that you specify is applied.
segment.target: If there are conflicts between two /md commands, the first rule that you specify is applied.

segment.source: For example, if you specify the and commands, then Corporate users would be mapped to the Fabrikam domain.
segment.target: For example, if you specify the and commands, then Corporate users would be mapped to the Fabrikam domain.

segment.source: If you specify an OldDomain that did not exist on the source computer, the LoadState command will appear to complete successfully, without an error or warning.
segment.target: If you specify an OldDomain that did not exist on the source computer, the LoadState command will appear to complete successfully, without an error or warning.

segment.source: However, in this case, users will not be moved to NewDomain but will remain in their original domain.
segment.target: However, in this case, users will not be moved to NewDomain but will remain in their original domain.

segment.source: For example, if you misspell contoso and you specify /md:contso:fabrikam, the users will remain in contoso on the destination computer.
segment.target: For example, if you misspell contoso and you specify /md:contso:fabrikam, the users will remain in contoso on the destination computer.

segment.source: Specifies a new user name for the specified user.
segment.target: Specifies a new user name for the specified user.

segment.source: If the store contains more than one user, you can specify multiple /mu options.
segment.target: If the store contains more than one user, you can specify multiple /mu options.

segment.source: You cannot use wildcard characters with this option.
segment.target: You cannot use wildcard characters with this option.

segment.source: Specifies that if a user account is a local (non-domain) account, and it does not exist on the destination computer, USMT will create the account on the destination computer but it will be disabled.
segment.target: Specifies that if a user account is a local (non-domain) account, and it does not exist on the destination computer, USMT will create the account on the destination computer but it will be disabled.

segment.source: To enable the account, you must also use the /lae option.
segment.target: To enable the account, you must also use the /lae option.

segment.source: If the /lac option is not specified, any local user accounts that do not already exist on the destination computer will not be migrated.
segment.target: If the /lac option is not specified, any local user accounts that do not already exist on the destination computer will not be migrated.

segment.source: Password is the password for the newly created account.
segment.target: Password is the password for the newly created account.

segment.source: An empty password is used by default.
segment.target: An empty password is used by default.

segment.source: Use the Password variable with caution because it is provided in plain text and can be obtained by anyone with access to the computer that is running the LoadState command.
segment.target: Use the Password variable with caution because it is provided in plain text and can be obtained by anyone with access to the computer that is running the LoadState command.

segment.source: Also, if the computer has multiple users, all migrated users will have the same password.
segment.target: Also, if the computer has multiple users, all migrated users will have the same password.

segment.source: For instructions, see Migrate User Accounts.
segment.target: For instructions, see Migrate User Accounts.

segment.source: Enables the account that was created with the /lac option.
segment.target: Enables the account that was created with the /lac option.

segment.source: You must specify the /lac option with this option.
segment.target: You must specify the /lac option with this option.

segment.source: For instructions, see Migrate User Accounts.
segment.target: For instructions, see Migrate User Accounts.

segment.source: The following examples apply to both the /ui and /ue options.
segment.target: The following examples apply to both the /ui and /ue options.

segment.source: You can replace the /ue option with the /ui option to include, rather than exclude, the specified users.
segment.target: You can replace the /ue option with the /ui option to include, rather than exclude, the specified users.

segment.source: Exclude the user named User One in the Corporate domain.
segment.target: Exclude the user named User One in the Corporate domain.

segment.source: Exclude the user named User1 in the Corporate domain.
segment.target: Exclude the user named User1 in the Corporate domain.

segment.source: Exclude the local user named User1.
segment.target: Exclude the local user named User1.

segment.source: Exclude users in all domains named User1, User2, and so on.
segment.target: Exclude users in all domains named User1, User2, and so on.

segment.source: You can use the /uel, /ue and /ui options together to migrate only the users that you want migrated.
segment.target: You can use the /uel, /ue and /ui options together to migrate only the users that you want migrated.

segment.source: The /ui option has precedence over the /ue and /uel options.
segment.target: The /ui option has precedence over the /ue and /uel options.

segment.source: If a user is specified to be included using the /ui option, and also specified to be excluded using either the /ue or /uel options, the user will be included in the migration.
segment.target: If a user is specified to be included using the /ui option, and also specified to be excluded using either the /ue or /uel options, the user will be included in the migration.

segment.source: For example, if you specify , then User1 will be migrated, because the /ui option takes precedence over the /ue option.
segment.target: For example, if you specify , then User1 will be migrated, because the /ui option takes precedence over the /ue option.

segment.source: The /uel option takes precedence over the /ue option.
segment.target: The /uel option takes precedence over the /ue option.

segment.source: If a user has logged on within the specified time period set by the /uel option, that user’s profile will be migrated even if they are excluded by using the /ue option.
segment.target: If a user has logged on within the specified time period set by the /uel option, that user’s profile will be migrated even if they are excluded by using the /ue option.

segment.source: For example, if you specify , the User1 will be migrated if they have logged on to the computer within the last 14 days.
segment.target: For example, if you specify , the User1 will be migrated if they have logged on to the computer within the last 14 days.

segment.source: Include only User2 from the Fabrikam domain and exclude all other users.
segment.target: Include only User2 from the Fabrikam domain and exclude all other users.

segment.source: Include only the local user named User1 and exclude all other users.
segment.target: Include only the local user named User1 and exclude all other users.

segment.source: Include only the domain users from Contoso, except Contoso\User1.
segment.target: Include only the domain users from Contoso, except Contoso\User1.

segment.source: This behavior cannot be completed using a single command.
segment.target: This behavior cannot be completed using a single command.

segment.source: Instead, to migrate this set of users, you will need to specify the following:
segment.target: Instead, to migrate this set of users, you will need to specify the following:

segment.source: Using the ScanState command-line tool, type:
segment.target: Using the ScanState command-line tool, type:

segment.source: Using the LoadState command-line tool, type:
segment.target: Using the LoadState command-line tool, type:

segment.source: The following table indicates which command-line options are not compatible with the LoadState command.
segment.target: The following table indicates which command-line options are not compatible with the LoadState command.

segment.source: If the table entry for a particular combination is blank, the options are compatible and you can use them together.
segment.target: If the table entry for a particular combination is blank, the options are compatible and you can use them together.

segment.source: The X symbol means that the options are not compatible.
segment.target: The X symbol means that the options are not compatible.

segment.source: For example, you cannot use the /nocompress option with the /encrypt option.
segment.target: For example, you cannot use the /nocompress option with the /encrypt option.

segment.source: You must specify either the /key or /keyfile option with the /encrypt option.
segment.target: You must specify either the /key or /keyfile option with the /encrypt option.
